terms.definition: A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to see revision history and revert to previous versions if needed.
A chronological record of all changes, edits, and access to documents that provides transparency and accountability for compliance purposes.
Standard Operating Procedure - a detailed, written instruction that describes how to perform a routine activity or process consistently.
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides searchable access to organizational knowledge and procedures.
A feature that allows multiple people to simultaneously edit and collaborate on the same document in real-time.
The process of organizing and formatting documents in a logical hierarchy to improve navigation, searchability, and user experience.
A system feature that automatically refreshes or modifies content when source information changes, reducing manual maintenance work.
Official documents and reports that organizations must submit to government agencies to demonstrate compliance with laws and regulations.
Work groups composed of members from different departments or areas of expertise who collaborate on shared objectives.
Automatically generated condensed versions of lengthy documents created using artificial intelligence to extract key information.
A unified system where all organizational documents are stored in a single, accessible location rather than scattered across multiple platforms.
The ongoing process of tracking and ensuring adherence to regulatory requirements, industry standards, and internal policies.
A software solution that provides tools for creating, managing, storing, and sharing documents electronically rather than on paper.
Formal documents and data packages submitted to regulatory authorities for approval, review, or compliance verification.
A digital storage system that allows users to quickly find specific information or documents using keywords, tags, or filters.
